III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The facility must ensure all staff are aware bed checks are completed at
variable intervals not to exceed 15 minutes. Most bed check logs were
completed as required, however, there were 2 bed check logs completed by
two different staff which reflected some checks at 15-minute intervals exactly,
which does not comply with the rule. This was determined to be a lack of

understanding by new staff rather than a facility-wide issue, therefore Chief
Administrator noted additional training will be provided.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• For reference, the following timeframes exist for interim and renewal inspection
visits/completion.
o Consultants can complete the on-site visit for renewal inspections up to
75 days prior to the license expiration date. The completed renewal
report is due to the area manager 30 days prior to the license expiration
date.
o Consultants can complete the on-site visit for interim inspections up to
60 days before or 60 days after the annual license date, however the
completed interim report is due to the area manager 30 days prior to 60
days after the annual license date.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
facility had one CAP as a result of their 2024 Interim Audit. The facility was found
in violation of the following rules and handled the rule violations in the following
ways:
• Rule 113(1)(I): The Chief Administrator verified and initialed the central
registry dates on the employee file cover check sheet when an
employee's start date was established and completed a CWL-1929 and
sent it to local office if the CWL-4624 was completed more than 30 days
prior to the employee's start date.
• Rule 155(1): The facility changed their process regarding youth going
AWOL from the program to ensure the youth were properly discharged
and treatment plan dates weren't affected. The treatment specialist also
created calendar reminders for the treatment plan due dates and copied
the Chief Administrator.
• Rule 166(1)(b)(e)(f): The facility created a new discharge summary form
which contained all the required information as part of the rule.

Financial Overview
A review of the facility’s financial budget and 2024 financial audit were completed,
and no concerns were noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) reported over the last year, they had 5 licensing rules
they worked to improve through a CAP, and they had successful implementation of
those action steps, which was confirmed by the facility having zero violations on
their 2025 renewal audit. CA noted the checklist created to identify the date of
employees’ initial central registry clearance was very helpful, and the new resident
discharge document created clearly lays out youths after care plans and
appointments, which has been helpful for discharged youth and their caregivers.
CA reported they will continue to hold weekly leadership meetings and monthly file
audits to ensure continued compliance.
Staff and Youth Interviews
One staff reported she enjoys influencing structure with the youth, transporting the
youth, and getting out to do activities with the youth. She reported she wishes
there were more effective consequences for major behaviors since the youth don't
go down in "level". She reported sometimes she feels the youth do not learn how
to correct their behaviors because the consequences aren't serious enough. She
reported she feels comfortable voicing her opinion, asking questions, and offering
suggestions. She reported she feels very supported, and she feels they have a
great team. She reported she feels the team is consistent in how they manage
expectations and situations in the home, and feels training prepared her well for
her role. She reported she especially valued and enjoyed the de-escalation
training. She reported she enjoys the facility offers youth opportunities for learning
such as raising caterpillars, cooking food, etc.
Another staff reported seeing youth change throughout the process, seeing how
much progress they make, and seeing how they flourish are the most rewarding
parts of the job. She reported she enjoys seeing how the youth are using their
tools and skills in group and during other hands-on experiences. She reported she
also likes seeing youth graduate after they are discharged from the facility and
come back to invite staff to celebrate their graduation. She reported she enjoys
doing college tours with the youth during spring break, so they can begin to create
new goals for themselves, have hope for the future, and see the "bigger picture" of
where their education can take them. She reported communication could always
be improved, especially in relation to making sure case notes are completed timely
in case there's no time for a conversation between shift changes. She reported

their staff turnover rate is higher because staff in college or straight out of college
don't understand how hard it is to work with teenagers. She reported they don't
have a good balance of staying firm and consistent while also being personable
and tend to try to be "friends" with the youth instead. She reported they have a lot
of activities and outings to keep the youth busy and get them out of the house
when they're not in school. She reported she feels supported in her role, feels
comfortable giving suggestions, and feels the facility administrators/managers
accept feedback well.
The supervisor reported there has been more turnover in staff recently due to
staff's individual education requirements and scheduling with college. The
supervisor reported although they're not fully staffed, they're staffed better than
they were last year, and have a lot more on-call staff, which has been a huge help.
The supervisor reported she feels supported in her role and she feels they have a
great team. The supervisor reported they have great communication amongst
employees, but feels it could always be improved, especially from one shift to
another.
Youth reported staff are nice, helpful and supportive. Youth reported the food is
great and they get enough food. Youth reported the groups in the home go well.
Youth reported they feel safe at the facility. One youth reported staff helped her
and supported her to meet her goals and achieve success in summer school,
school, worked with her to increase her grades and attendance, and provided the
necessary motivation to increase her performance as well as her interpersonal
skills.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of the facility was completed on 7/21/25 and 7/22/25 and there
were no safety concerns noted.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes. It is recommended that the agency be issued a renewal of their regular
license.
